abstract.p: Jeffrey Rice letter on Sept 16 article on Ellen Johnson, president of American Atheists

block.p: Re ''It's a Harsh Political Climate for a Believer in Nonbelief'' (Public Lives column, Sept. 16), about Ellen Johnson, president of American Atheists:
Re ''It's a Harsh Political Climate for a Believer in Nonbelief'' (Public Lives column, Sept. 16), about Ellen Johnson, president of American Atheists:

What is often not understood is that obligation to pray, be it a part of an oath or expected as part of a public ceremony, is no less uncomfortable for an atheist than a prayer to Allah would be to a Christian.

As an atheist myself, I respect the beliefs of my religious friends, and I understand how important religion is in their lives. What I expect in return is the recognition that I am able to lead a good, moral life without accepting religion in my own life.

I ask for the freedom to do so, without being singled out because I cannot and will not pretend to believe something I do not. To do so would be disrespectful to those who do believe, as well as immoral.
